settings.title: What is IBS?
settings.text: IBS is a common digestion condition that causes unpleasant symptoms in the abdomen. Symptoms usually include stomach cramps, bloating, diarrhoea and constipation. IBS can be a life-long problem but may be managed with diet changes and medication.

settings.title: Can IBS be treated?
settings.text: While there is no cure for IBS, there are ways to manage your symptoms. The painful stomach cramping can be treated through medication that can relax the stomach muscles. The diarrhoea, bloating and constipation symptoms can also be treated with specific medications

settings.title: of the general population is estimated to have IBS
settings.text: According to NICE, it is estimated that between 10-20% of the general population has IBS, though the number could be higher.

settings.title: of the population is likely to experience IBS symptoms each year
settings.text: According to NICE, each year 10% of the population will experience IBS symptoms.

settings.title: Buy IBS treatment online
settings.text: “There is no one-size-fits-all treatment for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), as the condition can vary greatly from person to person. IBS can cause a range of symptoms, including abdominal pain, bloating, diarrhea, and constipation. settings.title: What causes IBS?
settings.text: The exact cause of IBS is not yet known however, it is thought to be related to how fast your food passes through your gut. Other factors could include oversensitive nerves in the gut, stress and a family history of IBS.

settings.title: What is an IBS diet?
settings.text:
There isn't a specific diet that should be adhered to if you suffer from IBS but there are certain changes that could be beneficial.

Try to cook meals at home using fresh ingredients and avoid lots of fatty, spicy or processed foods. Find ways to relax and get plenty of exercise. You may also want to consider keeping a diary of foods that might be a trigger of IBS for you.

Try to avoid eating quickly and delaying or skipping meals. Don't drink too much coffee, tea, alcohol or fizzy drinks and try to eat no more than 3 portions of fresh fruit a day.

settings.title: Can you cure IBS permanently?
settings.text: There is no permanent cure for IBS but it can be managed through careful diet and medications.

settings.title: Does IBS need medication?
settings.text: Depending on your symptoms, some medications will help you with your IBS however, they are not needed.
